titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Hideyo Noguchi papers, Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research Scientific Staff FA121

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2016-10-16 04:04:19 -0400.

change.item: Paper finding aid converted to EAD/XML by AureXus in 2010. Imported into the Archvists’ Toolkit by Becky Robbins.

did.unittitle: Hideyo Noguchi papers, Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research Scientific Staff

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with “fair use”. If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users’ responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, photographs obituary and biographical articles, newspaper items, reprints.

The papers consist of administrative correspondence, May 1900-May 1928; a large collection of photographs, collection of snapshots, photographs from Accra, photographs of diplomas, honors and medals; a large number of biographical articles and bibliography; a number of obituary articles and some historical articles; letters written from Accra relating to his research and conditions of work; correspondence with family representatives from Japan and with representatives of the Doctor Noguchi Memorial Association in Japan.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for researchd. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biography: Hideyo Noguchi (1876-1928) Japanese born bacteriologist who came to The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research in 1904 and was successively Assistant, Associate Member and Member until his death in 1928. He worked closely with Simon Flexner. His first work was on the study of snake venoms. He then worked on collateral problems in immunology, syphilis and other forms of spirochetes and the etiological factors in Yellow Fever, Oroya Fever and trachoma. He served as bacteriologist of the Yellow Fever Commission sent by the International Health Board of The Rockefeller Foundation. He died at Accra, West Africa while on a project for the study of Yellow Fever.

Member of: American Association of Pathologists and Bacteriologists; Society for Experimental Biology and Medicine; Harvey Society; Society for Experimental Therapy and Pharmacology; Society for Clinical Serology and Haematology (President, Councilor); Gesellschaft für innere Medizin und Kinderheilkunde of Vienna; St Louis Medical Society of Syracuse (Honorary Member); Academy of Medicine of Suffolk Medical Society; Colorado State Medical Society; American Philosophical Society; Association of American Physicians; American Association for the Advancement of Science ; Sociedade de Antonio Alzate, Mexico City; Mexican National Academy; Société de Biologie, Paris (Corresponding member); Société de Pathologie Exotique, Paris; Norske medizinake Selskab (Christiana); Société de Dermatologie et Venéreologie, Moscow; Accademia Medico-fisica Fiorentina, Florence; Sociedad Medica de Caracas (Venezuela) ; American Society for Experimental Pathology

eventgrp.event: Knight of the Royal Order of Isabella la Catolica (Spain); Knight of the Royal Order of Dannebrog (Denmark)
Knight of the Order of the Pole Star (Sweden)
Order of the Rising Sun (Japan); Emporor's Medal and Premium, Imperial Academy of Japan
Hon. Senior Surgeon with rank of Colonel, Ecuadorean Army
Hon. M.D. School of Medicine and Pharmacology, Yucatan
Hon. Prof. University of Quayaquil; Hon. Prof. University of Quito
John Scott Medal, City of Philadelphia
Elected Member of Imperial Academy of Japan

Kober Medal, Association of American Physicians; Chevalier de la Légion d'Honneur, République de France; Medal from Elocution Soc. of Japan (one of 10 presented to 10 greatest Japanese); Medal from American Medical Association (Sc. Exhibit Yellow Fever, 1919); Medal from Asociacion Escuela de Medicina (Quayaquil); Medal from Asociacion de Empleados de Quayaquil and Los Centros de Trabajo (Quayaquil)
- Titular Professor, University of Education of the Imperial Government of Japan
Sc.D. Brown University; Sc.D. Yale University

scopecontent.p: 2 page copy sent to S. Flexner including an 8 page handwritten letter from Noguchi to Russell protesting situation in regard to purchase of animals and reports on findings; includes Mar. 16 and Mar. 20 cables from Russell to Noguchi (copies)

Henry R. Muller to S. Flexner recollection of laboratory situation in Accra. (Handwritten-3 pages)
Correspondence, notes, cables, clinical reports, hospital records and laboratory reports on last illness and death in Accra of Hideyo Noguchi.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The death of Noguchi was followed in 8 days by the death of William A. Young.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From Accra. Names of correspondents are: E. Morris Franklin (European Hospital); F.F. Russell, Director of International Health Division. Included are copies of correspondence from the American Consulate and British Colonial Office; copies of the autopsy report by N. Paul Hudson and Oskar Klotz; copies of diary, notes and letters from Henry Beeuwkes, Evelyn Tilden; A.F. Mahaffy; Helen Russell, pathologist; Agnes A. Young (mother) and Olive M. Young (wife) of Dr. William B. Young (picture included).

scopecontent.p: Deals mainly with details of Dr. Noguchi's estate and includes several handwritten letters from Mary Noguchi. Includes negotiations, lists and arrangements for items shipped to Japan and plans for a Memorial.
